text: Is JuMP a good tool for finding the vector c that maximizes f(c) = c^T A c / (c^T B c) (where A and B symmetric positive definite matrices) ?

elements.text: Is JuMP a good tool for finding the vector c that maximizes f(c) = c^T A c / (c^T B c) (where A and B symmetric positive definite matrices) ?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
Is it? ~I don't think so...~  I don't see how
I'm doing the algebra right now, as long as no component of c is zero, the term has no dependency on c
It's the same as minimizing sum_ij c_i A_ij c_j 1/c_i 1/B_ij 1/c_j

yeah but it's actually
(\sum_ij c_i c_j A_ij)/(\sum_ij c_i c_j B_ij).
It's two different sums, you can't collect them together

elements.text:
yeah but it's actually
(\sum_ij c_i c_j A_ij)/(\sum_ij c_i c_j B_ij).
It's two different sums, you can't collect them together

text: I don't see why i can't collect them together if there are no 0's

`julia> N=3`
`3`

`julia> c=randn(N); A=randn(N,N); B=randn(N,N); A=A*A'; B=B*B';`

`julia> c'*A*c/(c'*B*c) == c'*(A./B)*c`
`false`

elements.text: julia> c=randn(N); A=randn(N,N); B=randn(N,N); A=A*A'; B=B*B';
